title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" mandates coordination between state and local entities on cybersecurity with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection focusing on State and Local Coordination on Cybersecurity. The Center will assist State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections based on cybersecurity risks and potential harm. The Center will assist State and local governments in identifying information security protections based on cybersecurity risks and potential harm. The Center will work with State and local governments to provide tools and resources for information security, coordinating efforts to ensure effective implementation and resilience. The Center will coordinate a nationwide effort to ensure effective implementation of information security tools and resources for State and local governments. They will provide cybersecurity training and privacy training to address risks and incidents. The Center will provide privacy and civil liberties training to State and local governments related to cybersecurity. They will offer operational and technical assistance to implement information security tools and resources, including deploying technology for continuous threat diagnosis and mitigation. The Center will assist State and local governments in developing policies and procedures for coordinating vulnerability disclosures, conducting targeted operational evaluations, and analyzing data on information security. The Center will assist State and local governments in developing policies and procedures for coordinating vulnerability disclosures and ensuring awareness of information security resources and guidelines. The Department and other Federal departments provide tools, products, resources, policies, guidelines, and procedures for securing Federal information systems. Privacy and civil liberties training includes processes consistent with Fair Information Practice Principles. The Department's cybersecurity measures must align with the Fair Information Practice Principles, limit unnecessary information collection, and prioritize privacy and civil liberties. The cybersecurity measures must protect information systems from risks, minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties, ensure data integrity by removing obsolete information, and safeguard cyber threat indicators. The Center must safeguard cybersecurity risk information, protect sensitive data, and ensure legal and privacy protections are followed. Congressional oversight is required within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center of the Department of Homeland Security must report on its activities and effectiveness to congressional committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment, focusing on State and local information security. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center must report on the effectiveness of its activities on State and local information security to congressional committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment, seeking feedback from State and local governments. The House of Representatives passed the information required under this subsection on December 10, 2015. Clerk: KAREN L. HAAS.
